title: Phrack Pro-Phile X
historical_context: This article is part of the Phrack Pro-Phile series, which profiles influential figures in the hacking and phreaking community during the 1980s.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture history.
short_summary: This article profiles Terminus, a notable sysop and hacker from the 1980s, detailing his journey through the early days of computing, phreaking, and bulletin board systems.
summary:
In this installment of Phrack Pro-Phile, Taran King interviews Terminus, a prominent figure in the hacking community known for his sysop roles in various bulletin board systems such as MetroNet and NetSys Unix. Terminus shares his experiences starting from building his own 6800 homebrew system to running sophisticated multi-user systems on Altos 986es. His journey reflects the evolution of personal computing and the burgeoning hacker culture of the time, highlighting the technical challenges and innovations he faced along the way.

Terminus discusses his early influences, including a friend from the phone company who introduced him to phreaking, and his eventual transition into hacking. He expresses nostalgia for the early days of the community, noting a decline in camaraderie among hackers. The article also touches on his professional background as an electrical engineer and his views on the ethical implications of hacking and phreaking. Overall, this profile serves as a snapshot of a pivotal era in computer history, showcasing the passion and ingenuity of early hackers like Terminus.
